sections.title: Intro Scenario
sections.text: The city of Mesa has just approved its **{General Plan}** for the next **20** years. The plan outlines areas for residential neighborhoods, commercial zones, parks, and {preserved natural spaces}.

sections.title: Question 1
sections.text: How long is the general plan good for?

sections.title: Answer 1
sections.text: 20 years

sections.title: Question 2
sections.text: Does the general plan include plans for both commercial and residential zones?

sections.title: Answer 2
sections.text: Yes, it includes plans for both residential and commercial. It also includes plans for parks and natural spaces that are meant to be preserved.

sections.title: Explanation
sections.text: A {General Plan} is a long-term guide that cities use to plan and regulate development in an orderly way. That’s why the city of Mesa approved its General Plan for the next 20 years. It's a document that's designed to outline how the city will grow and develop over time. It includes plans for residential neighborhoods, commercial zones, parks, and natural spaces, but it doesn’t get into the specific details of individual developments. The fact that the general plan doesn't get into specific recreational areas is what's important. That's what sets it apart from a master plan.

sections.title: Scenario Continued
sections.text: Developer Sarah sees an opportunity to propose a {Master Planned Community} that fits the plan's vision. Her community will include family homes, parks and jogging trails, ensuring alignment with the city's long-term goals.

sections.title: Question 3
sections.audioFile: 8 Q3 How specific does a General Plan get？.mp3
sections.text: How specific does a General Plan get?

sections.title: Answer 3
sections.text: General Plans have a broad focus on land use categories. For example, an area might be designated for medium density residential, which covers a range of housing types but not individual lot sizes or exact building designs. It moreso outlines policies and goals for the future, such as supporting affordable housing initiatives. General plans often include maps showing intended land use patterns, transportation networks, and areas for land conservation. You won't see specific landscaping requirements or building footprints in a general plan.

sections.title: Question 4
sections.audioFile: 10 Q4 How specific does a Master Plan get？.mp3
sections.text: How specific does a Master Plan get?

sections.title: Answer 4
sections.text: A {Master Plan} is far more specific than a General Plan, as it focuses on the detailed design and development of a particular area or large-scale community. In a master plan, you'll see focus on a specific area, often a large scale project. It includes individual parcels for homes, businesses, recreational spaces, street layouts, sidewalks and bike paths, jogging trails, and placement of community features like parks, schools or shopping areas. A Master Plan specifies what buildings go where and even the building styles and materials. Sarah believes her Master Plan aligns with the General Plan's general goal, but beyond that, the specifics of what she's designing are her own.

sections.title: Sarah's Story Cont.
sections.text: To get started, Sarah drafts a **{Master Deed}** to divide the community into individual lots and parcels for future homes and amenities.

sections.title: Question 5
sections.audioFile: 13 Q5 what does Sarah draft after master plan.mp3
sections.text: What does Sarah draft after her master plan is approved?

sections.title: Answer 5
sections.audioFile: 14 Q5A Sarah drafts a master deed.mp3
sections.text: Sarah drafts a master deed

sections.title: Question 6
sections.text: Why did Sarah draft a master deed?

sections.title: Answer 6
sections.text: She did it to divide the community into individual lots and parcels for future homes and amenities in the specific area she's planning for.

sections.title: Master Deed Explained
sections.text: A master deed is a legal document that officially divides the planned community into individual lots or parcels for specific purposes and ownership.

sections.title: Question 7
sections.audioFile: 18 Q7 What does a master deed divide？.wav
sections.text: What does a master deed divide?

sections.title: Answer 7
sections.audioFile: 19 Q7A A master deed divides the land into parcels.mp3
sections.text: A master deed divides the land into parcels for developing individual properties.

sections.title: Question 7 Explained
sections.text: You heard that Sarah's {Master Planned Community} included family homes, parks, and jogging trails. The Master Deed was what allowed her to divide the land into separate sections. Some for residential lots, others for recreational spaces, and even areas to preserve as natural open spaces. If there's no master deed, there is no contract that formalizes what plot of land is for what, and where boundaries are.

sections.title: NAOS
sections.text: Sarah identifies a {Natural Area Open Space} (NAOS) that will remain undeveloped to preserve the local environment. The city is impressed with how well the NAOS fits the general plan, and gives the greenlight for construction.

sections.title: Question 8
sections.audioFile: 22 Q8 What is a Natural Area Open Space？.wav
sections.text: What is a Natural Area Open Space?

sections.title: Answer 8
sections.audioFile: 23 Q8A A Natural Area Open Space, is a designated area or easement preserved in its natural state to protect the environment.wav
sections.text: A {Natural Area Open Space} (NAOS) is a designated area or easement preserved in its natural state to protect the environment and limit development.

sections.title: Question 9
sections.audioFile: 24 Q9 Can you recall what a master deed divides.wav
sections.text: Can you recall what a Master Deed divides?

sections.title: Answer 9
sections.audioFile: 25 Q9A For developing individual properties, a master deed divides.wav
sections.text: For developing individual properties, a **Master Deed** divides the land into individualized parcels.

sections.title: Question 10
sections.audioFile: 26 Q10 Regarding specificity, what is the difference between a General Plan and a Master Plan.wav
sections.text: Regarding specificity, what is the difference between a General Plan and a Master Plan?

sections.title: Answer 10
sections.audioFile: 27 Q10A Master plans can get highly specific.wav
sections.text: Master plans can get highly specific, whereas general plans get as specific as zoning land and placing transportation networks.

sections.title: Story 2 Start: The Digging Dilemma
sections.text: When planning a new office building in Scottsdale, architect Mark consults the **{Site Plan}** to ensure all improvements are properly laid out. The Site Plan includes details like the **Building Footprint**, which shows where the structure will sit on the property.

sections.title: Question 11
sections.audioFile: 29 Q11 What did Mark the architect consult.wav
sections.text: What did Mark the architect consult to make sure improvements are properly laid out?

sections.title: Answer 11
sections.audioFile: 30 Q11A Mark consulted the site plan to see how everything will be arranged on the land.wav
sections.text: Mark consulted the **Site Plan** to see how everything will be arranged on the land.

sections.title: Site Plan Defined
sections.text: A Site Plan is a detailed architectural document that illustrates the proposed development and layout of a specific parcel of land. It provides a visual representation of how the land will be used and what structures or {improvements} will be made. You'll see parking and traffic flow, landscaping, and, of course, the **building footprint**.

sections.title: Question 12
sections.audioFile: 32 Q12 Site Plan vs Master Plan.wav
sections.text: What kind of area does a Site Plan focus on? And what kind of area does a Master Plan focus on?

sections.title: Answer 12
sections.text: A Master Plan focuses on a large community or area, whereas a Site Plan focuses on a specific parcel.

sections.title: Site Plan Explanation
sections.text: The Site Plan includes details like the {Building Footprint}, which shows where the structure will sit on the property, as well as utility lines, parking lots, and landscaping.

sections.title: Building Footprint
sections.text: A **{Building Footprint}** refers to the specific area of land that is occupied by a building or structure, as seen from a top-down (bird's-eye) view. It is essentially the outline of the building on the site, including its external walls and any attached structures like porches, decks, or garages. It has Defined Boundaries, meaning The footprint includes only the physical space occupied by the building itself. Landscaping for the parcel is something different.

sections.title: Question 13
sections.text: Imagine you’re reviewing a **site plan** for a new office building. How would you describe the **building footprint** to your client?

sections.title: Answer 13
sections.text: The {Building Footprint} shows what ground area is covered by the building, and what the outline of a building is when looking at it from above.

sections.title: Question 14
sections.text: Is it the site plan or the building footprint that includes things like utility lines, parking lots, and landscaping?

sections.title: Answer 14
sections.text: That would be the site plan. In fact, the site plan includes the building footprint for the parcel.

sections.title: Story 2 Continued
sections.text: Before any digging begins, Mark wants to know the the construction team won't accidentally hit a water or gas line, and so he calls **Arizona 811** to mark the underground utilities on the site.

sections.title: Question 15
sections.text: What service does Mark call to find out where underground utilities are?

sections.title: Answer 15
sections.text: Arizona 811

sections.title: Story Continued
sections.text: And so Mark calls **Arizona 811** to mark the underground utilities on the site. Once the utilities are clearly identified, the construction team starts digging with confidence, knowing they won’t accidentally hit a water or gas line. Thanks to Mark’s thorough planning, the project stays on schedule and avoids costly mistakes.

sections.title: Question 16
sections.text: Is is the site plan or **Arizona 811** that shows existing utility lines?

sections.title: Answer 16
sections.text: Site Plans for existing properties show existing utility lines if they are relevant to the project. Site Plans for New Construction focus on proposed utility lines, but just might indicate nearby existing utilities to connect to. Even if existing utilities are shown on a site plan a developer is using, their exact location should be confirmed and physically marked by contacting **Arizona 811** before digging.

sections.title: Intro Scenario
sections.text: The town of Greenview is holding a public hearing to discuss a new **zoning ordinance**. The **zoning ordinance** proposed zoning an unused chunk of land on the edge of town to residential use to accommodate a growing population.

sections.title: Question 1
sections.text: What new thing is being discussed at the public hearing?

sections.title: Answer 1
sections.text: A zoning ordinance.

sections.title: Explanation
sections.text: A **zoning ordinance** is a government regulation that controls how land can be used in a specific area. It’s enacted by municipalities, such as cities or counties, under their police powers to ensure orderly development and protect public welfare. That’s why, in the story, Greenview held a public hearing to decide whether farm land could be re-zoned for residential use. Public hearings are a key part of creating zoning ordinances—they give the community a chance to voice concerns and provide input.

sections.title: Story Continued
sections.text: During the discussion, the city planner explained that the ordinance would create a Buffer Zone of trees and open land between the new neighborhood and the remaining farmland.

sections.title: Question 2
sections.text: What would be contained within the buffer zone, and what would it separate?

sections.title: Answer 2
sections.text: The buffer zone would contain trees and open land, separating the new neighborhood and the remaining farmland zones.
